So one valence electron of sodium is accepted by chlorine and they both combine to form a stable molecule which is has less potential energy than the elements in the molecule. Hydrogen has 1 electron overall and needs 1 more for a duplet. So oxygen shares the electron with two hydrogen atoms to form a covalent compound.  So ionic and covalent differ in the way of bond formation. Ionic compound have high melting and boiling point that covalent compound as it involves complete transfer of electron because of which there is strong electrostatic force of attraction between the molecules. This happens to be an excellent question, and I am not sure this answer is adequate. At the extremes, it is simple. The covalent bond forms by two electrons occupying a common wave function that is bound by two atoms. Contrary to what many will say, the electrons do not have to come from different atoms. Thus the compound formed with the structure BH3NH3 has all the physical properties of a covalent bond, but the lone pair of ammonia provides both electrons. One of the key properties is the structure is fixed and usually has a fixed structure that is maintained at all times, other than the breaking of the compound. An ionic compound is one where the two electrons reside on one atom, one of which has been transferred to make the pair on the anion that, apart from net charge, behaves like a lone pair. Typically, they have no structure other than the packing of opposite charges which is defined by the ions size. Ionic compounds dissolve in solvents that can provide polarization stabilization. The problem arises with certain compounds described as having ionic nature. These have structure but large dipoles in their bonds and can dissociate at est partially in solution. These tend to involve metals with large valence. Ionic and covalent bonds are a man-made classifications to make understanding how atoms interact more easily. At this point in education, they have become scripture and often prevent understanding instead of helping it. When two atoms are close to each other, they have a go at each other’s electrons. What happens depends on how strong the nucleus of each atom pulls on the other’s electrons. That, in turn depends on other things. There is a measure of how strong an atom pulls electrons - it’s called electronegativity.  If both atoms pull with about equal strength, then they are at an impasse. They may end up sharing electrons. They form a molecule. This is called covalent bonding by almost everyone.  If one atom pulls much strongly than the other, then it may strip off an electron completely. If this happens, you end up with two ions - the atom with the extra electron is a negative ion, and the atom which has lost the electron is a positive ion. What happens next depends on where your ions are. If they are in water, then water molecules surround the ions. They become part of water mesh. If they are not in water, then the ions tend to arrange themselves in a more or less organized structure. Think of how metal flakes arrange themselves in a magnetic field. This is similar to that. Because of the electromagnetic forces of the ions, the ions arrange themselves in orderly ways. The end result is a crystal solid. People generally point a finger at this process and call it ionic bonding. Some call the bonds between ions in the crystal ionic bonds. There are no such bonds in water, however. Some skip on the definition and waterwash by explaining properties of ionic compounds. So there is no single good definition of an ionic bond.  Random stupid stuff people say about bonds:“Some atoms want to lose electrons” - No atom wants to lose an electron. Some pull on electrons less strongly. “Atoms become more stable by losing/gaining electrons” - Atoms become less stable by losing/gaining electrons: A lone ion is more unstable than a lone atom. An ion in a crystal is however, is more stable than the comparable atom. The process of becoming a crystal increases stability. This is why ionic bonds and ionic compounds cannot really be studied separately - the stability increase due to crystal formation drives the entire thing forward.

There are two types of atomic bonds - ionic bonds and covalent bonds. They differ in their structure and properties. Covalent bonds consist of pairs of electrons shared by two atoms, and bind the atoms in a fixed orientation. Relatively high energies are required to break them (50 - 200 kcal/mol). Whether two atoms can form a covalent bond depends upon their electronegativity i.e. the power of an atom in a molecule to attract electrons to itself. If two atoms differ considerably in their electronegativity - as sodium and chloride do - then one of the atoms will lose its electron to the other atom. This results in a positively charged ion (cation) and negatively charged ion (anion). The bond between these two ions is called an ionic bond. For more information please watch the below video :

The difference between ionic and covalent bonding is how the electrons are distributed and shared between the atoms. In ionic bonding a cation and an anion meet and the cation transfers its lost electron to the anion which, in turn, gains an electron. However, in covalent bonding the electrons are shared between the overlap region of the two or more orbitals of the atoms. Ionic bonding usually results in stronger bonds than covalent bonds because of Coulomb's Law. This can be explained by comparing the boiling points of covalent compounds with that of ionic compounds. It is pretty obvious that if ionic bonds have stronger bonds than covalent bonds then they should have a higher boiling point because it would take more energy to break the bonds between them.

Well, the modern covalent bond is conceived to be a region of high electron density BETWEEN two positively charged atomic nuclei, such that electrostatic attraction of the nuclei to the electronic cloud overcomes electrostatic repulsion between the positively charged nuclei, and a net attractive force results, On the other hand, we conceive that ionic bonding occurs when an electron-rich, reducing material, a metal, transfers electrons to an electron-poor, oxidizing material, a non-metal. And electrostatic attraction between the positive and negative ions results in a strong, non-molecular bond. And this is what we mean in elementary chemistry when we describe ionic bonding as the result of the transfer of electrons to form discrete ions, and covalent bonding results from the SHARING of electrons. Ionic bonding typically results in non-molecular materials, whereas covalent bonding can result in both non-molecular materials, AND discrete MOLECULES.

Think in this way. In both cases we have overlapping of orbitals. Thus, we have significant electron density in the space region of the bond. In non-polar covalent bonds the electron density on the bond is between the two atoms. In covalent polar bonds electron density is withdrawn to the more electronegative atom. In the extreme case of withdrawing of electron density we have ionic bond. If the electron is completely withdrawn , which happens in polar solvents ,e.g., water, we have ions.
